title: Yarner Woods Walking Route

images.title: Derek Harper / Path, Yarner Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: As this path veers across a gridline, it emerges into a more open stretch, the trees set back on either side.

images.title: Derek Harper / Common Cow-wheat, Yarner Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Common Cow-wheat. In many woods on the edge of Dartmoor Melampyrum pratense is the dominant flowering plant in early summer. Here it is growing in a relatively open position by a path across the central hill in the nature reserve.

images.title: Martin Bodman / Bovey Tracey: Haytor Tramway in Yarner Woods, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bovey Tracey: Haytor Tramway in Yarner Woods. Haytor Quarries on Dartmoor were opened circa 1820 and a means of transporting the granite to New Quay, Teignmouth  whence it was shipped to the metropolis and used in the construction of London Bridge, now in Arizona  had to be devised. An 8.5 mile tramway was constructed from granite blocks quarried at Haytor, linking the quarries with the Stover Canal at Teigngrace. Barges then conveyed the cut granite to waiting vessels at Teignmouth. The tramway gauge was about four foot and the trucks, each carrying up to 3 tons, were horse drawn.

images.title: Derek Harper / Yarner Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Looking south-east across the northern of the two valleys that cross this square, which is almost entirely filled by the western part of Yarner Wood nature reserve.

images.title: Derek Harper / Ride, Yarner Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Ride, Yarner Wood. This ride runs along a terrace on the south side of the Yarner Stream valley (right) and must surely be associated with the nearby copper mine, but does not appear on the 1:25000 map.

images.title: Natasha Bos / Yarner Wood in the Autumn, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Yarner Wood in the Autumn. Abundance of trees with autumnal colours...fast approaching winter

images.title: Derek Harper / Path in Yarner Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: A trickle of water has become a small stream thanks to recent heavy rain, at this sharp bend where a path turns beside an ash tree to run along the contour on the southern side of the Yarner Stream valley.

images.title: Derek Harper / Buildings in Yarner Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Buildings in the woods. The nature trail around the reserve passes these, which stand in the valley bottom below the remains of the Yarrow Cooper Mine.

description: This large woodland area near Bovey Tracey is part of the East Dartmoor Woods and Heaths National Nature Reserve. It's a great area for walking with miles of woodland paths to follow. The area is dominated by ancient oak but there are other species such as birch, scots pine, larch and beech. Other flora includes flowers such as cow-wheat and bilberry, and various Lichens and mosses. Look out for an abundance of wildlife including doormice and butterflies. Birdlife includes pied flycatcher, redstart, buzzards, sparrow hawks and nightjars.This circular walk starts at the car park at the eastern end of the woods but you could also follow the Templer Way from nearby Bovey Tracey to reach the woods.
